description.en:
The course format is lectures and seminars. The course consists of lectures on conflict resolution and techniques on mediation and negotiation. The lectures are followed by seminars. There are three simulation seminars sandwiched between introductory and wrap-up seminars. For every class, students are expected to have read the course materials, have prepared for the seminar and actively take part in the discussions in seminars.
In lectures main techniques of mediation and negotiation are covered and discussed. The course builds on 'Conflict Management and Resolution' course but adds an in-depth analysis of some topics. 
In simulation seminars, each participant will receive a role either as a warring party, a mediator or an interested party, which she or he will be representing. There are five parties in each conflict so the work is done in groups rather than individually. Each party has a mandate they will be following throughout the negotiations. 
Each seminar will end with a class discussion on linking the issues covered during the simulation to the more general context of conflict resolution.
description.et:
Kursus koosneb loengutest ja seminaridest. Algselt on loengud konfliktilahendustest ning vahendusest ja läbirääkimistest. Loengutele järgnevad seminarid. Kolm simulatsiooniseminari on sissejuhatava ja kokkuvõtvate seminaride vahel. Igaks seminariks peavad tudengid lugema kursusematerjale, seminariks ette valmistama ning aruteludes aktiivselt osalema. 
Loengutes käsitletakse vahenduse ja läbirääkimiste tehnikaid. Kursus annab juurde kursusele "Conflict Management and Resolution" kuna lisa teemasid ning süvaanalüüsi.

objectives.en:
The course is part of the elective subject module of the curriculum. The main general purpose of the course is to complement compulsory courses with an alternative angle on conflict studies. 
The particular aim of the course is to explore the dynamics and the complexity of the decision-making process of peace negotiations of intrastate and internal conflicts. The course examines the range of strategies, roles and interests of internal and external parties to the mediation process through a simulation of selected peace talks. Students use their knowledge from the course 'Conflict Management and Resolution' and combine it with practical skills of negotiations through the simulation.
Above all, participants will learn concrete negotiation skills that can be applied in real-life situations.
objectives.et: Kursus on valikaine, mille peamine eesmärk on täiendada kohustuslikke kursusi rahvusvahelisele konfliktile uue vaatenurga andmisega. Kursuse konkreetne eesmärk on uurida nii riikidevaheliste kui siseriiklike konfliktide rahuläbirääkimiste otsusetegemiste dünaamikat ja komplekssust. Kursuse käigus käsitletakse simulatsioonin abil konfliktipoolte ning väliste toimijate erinevaid strateegiaid vahenduse käigus. Tudengid kasutavad oma teadmisi ainest "Conflict Management and Resolution" ning kombineerivad neid läbirääkimistel vajalike praktiliste oskustega. Neid oskusi kursuse käigus õpitakse ning neid on võimalik kohaldada ka väljaspool kursust.

learning_outcomes.en: Upon completion of the course, the students will be able to:
1. Cement their theoretical knowledge acquired in previous courses;
learning_outcomes.et: 1. Kinnistavad eelnevates kursustes õpitud teoreetilised teadmised;

learning_outcomes.en: 2. Be better prepared to use the theoretical knowledge and critical thinking about conflict resolutions in practical situations and link learned negotiation skills with these situations;
learning_outcomes.et: 2. On valmis kasutama mainitud teoreetilisi teadmisi ja kriitilist mõtlemist konfliktilahendusest praktilistes olukordades ning siduma õpitud läbirääkimisoskused nende olukordadega;

learning_outcomes.en: 3. Understand the complexities of conflict related negotiations;
learning_outcomes.et: 3. Saavad aru konfliktidega seotud läbirääkimiste keerukusest;

learning_outcomes.en: 4. Combine the range of strategies and options available in conflict situations whenever they may emerge.
learning_outcomes.et: 4. Oskavad erinevaid strateegiaid ja valikuid kohaldada igale võimalikule konfliktiolukorrale;

learning_outcomes.en: 5. Consider different aspects of conflict setting (culture, ethnicity, gender, history and economics) as they could affect both the conflict as well as its resolution.
learning_outcomes.et: 5. Oskavad arvestada erinevaid konfliktitaustu (kultuur, etnilisus, sugu, ajalugu, majandus), kuna need võivad omada mõju lahendusele

notes.et:
Classroom etiquette:
Please come to class on time and well prepared. While in class, turn off mobile phones. Laptops are allowed in class but please refrain from using them on non-related issues. Reading news, playing games, messaging and using social media etc are not allowed. Students who systematically keep engaged in these activities are asked to leave the classroom and their status will be considered to be 'absent' (see above).
Plagiarism is not tolerated. All written work for this course should include proper citations in a standard citation format. If unsure how to quote, ask for help. "I wasn't sure how to cite a source, so I left out the reference," is not an acceptable defence for plagiarism.

independent_work.et:
Reflection papers (60% of the grade) which involve:
a. Reflection papers I - III (group assignment, 500-700 words, 10% of the final grade each) - due before the simulation seminars (weeks 4-6), this paper reflects how the student understands his/her role. Paper focuses on the policy of the side they are representing. It is not a neutral outline, it should explore the reasons behind interests and policies of a particular party. The paper will serve as a mandate for the participant during the simulation. As the mandate is divided between groups, these papers are group assignments. 

b. Reflection paper IV (individual papers, 2200-2500 words, 30% of the final grade) - due after the course. Students will write reflection paper exploring their new understanding of global conflict resolution. The paper should bring in global conflict theories, course readings and theories, and experiences as part of the simulation. It should discuss the outcome of the peace process of the chosen conflict, drawing both on the theoretical and empirical literature covered in class and must demonstrate the understanding of the complexities of the peace negotiations.

description.et: Reflection papers I - III (group assignment, 500-700 words, 10% of the final grade each)
Reflection paper IV (individual papers, 2200-2500 words, 30% of the final grade)
Active participation in seminars (40% of the final grade)

grade_preconditions.et: Students must attend most seminars and lectures! Out of three simulations, student must attend at least two. Missing a seminar is excused only with a relevant reason (for example, illness).

grade_evaluation.et:
Participation in class (40% of the grade) which involves:
a. Attendance - students are expected to attend every seminar and lecture. Absence is allowed only in special cases (for example illness) but these cases must be proved on evidence rather than claims by student.
b. Preparation for seminars and lectures - students are expected to work through the readings prior to seminar. 
c. Active participation is discussions - students must be actively taking part in the seminars not just attend them. Merely showing up for the seminar does not represent participation.
Reflection papers (see above).

debt_elimination.et: As seminars include simulations that cannot be re-done, then there is no possibilities to get a grade after missing more than one of these seminars.
